Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: TAKE care, little girl, that you do not fall into the water; for if

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: once you fell in, you could not get out again, unless somebody happened

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: to come to your assistance. When you are sent by your mother to fetch

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: water, you should be careful how you dip your jug in; and after it is

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: filled, you should go steadily home, without playing by the way.

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: Dearest Fanny, come to me,

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: Take and eat my sweet grass here;

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: Once you never us'd to flee,

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: When with joy I did appear.

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: But now, your lambkin by your side

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: Takes all your thoughts and all your care;

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: I may go, and run, and ride,

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: You are careless how, or where.

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: "Turnips, cabbages, carrots, Ho! Now try, Ma'am; I dare say you and

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: I can agree upon a price for this bunch of turnips: they were fresh

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: gathered this morning, I assure you; and I think if you buy of me once,

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: you will never buy of any body else.--Pray, Ma'am, try my fine, fresh

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: codlins. They are very cheap, and as large as you can get any where."

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: How quiet that cow seems, which Molly the dairy-maid has just been

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: milking. In some parts of the world there are wild cows, and buffaloes

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: too, which will kill those who attack them, if they can; but in this

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: happy island, there are no fierce wild beasts, to frighten us from the

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: fields by day, or disturb our slumbers by night.

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: To Brighton or Worthing, and all with full speed,

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: Which way are you going so mightily fast?

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: Take care of the reins, for your mettlesome steed

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: Might stumble and lay you too low at the last.

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: With spurs and with boots you are finely set out,

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: To take a long journey o'er hill and o'er dale;

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: But remember one thing--'tis of mighty import--

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: Your poney may founder, and all his strength fail.

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: And you, too, confess, when you weary have been,

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: At the end of your journey, wherever you roam;

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: That, tho' houses, and parks, and fine rivers you've seen,

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: There's no place so happy, so sweet as your home.

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: _No. 6.--Man and Woman._

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: Ah, poor people, how sorry I am for you! I hope you have not far to go

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: before you see your nice little cottage. It is dismal walking in such

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: weather; but as you are caught in the rain, you must make the best of

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: your way, and be thankful you have a home to shelter you.

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: _No. 7.--The Gravel-pit._

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: How industriously these men are working. One is picking down the hard

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: gravel, with a pick-axe: the other is taking it up with a shovel, and

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: putting it into a sieve. All the small pieces go through, and the great

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: stones remain. The sifted gravel, I suppose, will be carried in a cart

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: to some gentleman's garden, to make walks; and the stones will be used

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: in mending the roads.

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: _No. 8.--Gardener._

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: "May I dig a little for you, father? I am sure I can dig very nicely,

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: if you will but let me try"--"And I can pull up the weeds," said little

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: Jane.--"You are both mistaken," replied their father: "you, John, have

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: not strength to put the spade far enough into the hard ground; and you,

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: Jane, would be apt to pull up flowers as well as weeds: and so you must

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: both be satisfied to work in your own little gardens for the present,

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: till the one is stronger, and the other wiser."

PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: _No. 9.--The Well._

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: The man who is drawing up water from the well, appears to have rather

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: hard work. Wells are very useful things: in them is collected a great

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: quantity of water, which can be drawn up by means of a rope and bucket;

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: and though it is some trouble to do this, we must be willing to take

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: it, for the sake of getting such a useful, pleasant thing as water.

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: _No. 10.--Little Girl and Ducks._

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: "Oh you pretty little duck, how I I should like to nurse you," said

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: Amelia. "That would be a great unkindness," replied her father: "the

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: little duck is fond of being in the water, and by the side of its

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: mother; and therefore it would be quite unhappy in your warm hands.

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: Little ducks and chickens run to their mother the moment they hear

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: her call; and little boys and girls should be obedient to their kind

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: parents, because they love them affectionately."

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: _No. 11.--Boys and Ass._

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: I am glad to see these boys are not teasing their ass, but, on the

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: contrary, are taking pleasure in putting a bough on its head, to keep

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: the flies off. Some boys are very cruel to poor asses. The dog in this

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: picture seems to be rather angry at something, but I cannot think at

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: what; for these good boys look as if they were kind to him, as well as

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: to their donkey.

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,

PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: _No. 12.--Children and Chaise._

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: Oh! how delightful and charming

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: To take the fresh air in a chaise;

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: To gallop along without harming:

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: Whip away! what a dust you do raise!

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: Of trees and of ponds too beware;

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: Mind likewise to treat well your ass;

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: And then, with attention and care,

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: Your time will in happiness pass.

line: _No. 13.--Chopping Wood._

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: This man has in his hand a bill, and he is probably going to cut up the

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: tree for fire-wood. The little girl seems to be catching the chips, to

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: carry home to her mother. What a nice thing it is to see a little girl

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: employed in helping her father; which, indeed, all little girls ought

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: to endeavour to do, because most parents do a great deal for their

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: children; and some have, like this man, to work _very hard for them_.

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: _No. 14.--Harvest Field._

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: Oh! what a delightful sight is the harvest-field. Our great Creator has

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: made the corn grow, to make nice food for the use of man. One of these

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: men is cutting down the corn, and the other is binding it up into a

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: sheaf; whilst those at a distance are carrying a waggon-full home, to

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: put into the barn. They have got a little cask of beer, which is a

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: necessary refreshment, after having worked hard in the hot sun.

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: _No. 15.--Blind Man._

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: To kindest pity now inclin'd,

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: See these children wish to give

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: A trifle to the poor and blind,

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: Thus assisting him to live.

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: See, all ragged and forlorn,

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: He is resting by a tree;

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: And to him the light of morn

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: And shades of eve alike must be.

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: Kind pity then, thou blessed gift,

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: Help and relieve the sore distress'd;

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: And up to heav'n his heart he'll lift,

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: That you with mercy may be blest.

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: This man is sowing seed, perhaps wheat or oats. The ground has been

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: prepared by ploughing and harrowing. That box holds the seed. After the

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: field is sown, a boy will be set to keep off the birds, which would

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: otherwise come and eat up a great deal of it.

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: "Remark," said a fond mother to her little girl, whilst admiring a fine

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: flock of sheep feeding in a green meadow, "how good our Heavenly

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: Father is to all his creatures. He makes the grass, to serve the sheep

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: for a soft couch to lie down upon when they are tired, and to afford

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: them a pleasant meal when they are hungry."

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,

PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: _No. 18.--Mother and Children._

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: Some people are rich, and have plenty of every thing they wish for;

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: whilst others are poor, and are obliged to be contented with few

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: things. The rich farmer gives his poor neighbours leave to pick up the

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: ears of corn that are scattered about, to make them a few loaves in the

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: winter. See that cottager, with a load upon her head: her eldest girl

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: is helping her; and a chubby little boy trudges joyfully by her side.

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: _No. 19.--Errand Cart._

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: If you have any parcels to send, good people, pray make haste and

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: overtake this man, who is called an errand-man. He makes it his

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: business to carry parcels, for which you must pay him a small sum. His

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: dog probably guards his parcels, when he has occasion to stop at a

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: house and leave his cart.

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: _No. 20.--Mill._

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: Within this mill are two very large stones: one of them is kept quite

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: quiet, whilst the other is moved round; and the corn being put between

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: them, is ground to a powder. Afterwards, all the coarse parts of the

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: husk are taken away by means of sifting: this coarse part is called

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: bran; and the fine white inside is flour, of which bread is made.

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: _No. 21.--Dobbin._

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: "Whoa, Dobbin!" says a man to his horse: "if you go further into the

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: pond, I shall have to follow you, which I shall not like, with my shoes

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: and stockings on." The other horse is drinking very quietly. What a

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: pleasant thing to have a nice pond to go to when they are thirsty;

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: and I hope the men also have got a nice supper at home, and kind wives

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: and children to welcome their return.

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: "Chick, chick, chick, here is some corn for you, and crumbs of bread

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: and cheese, which mamma saved for you after dinner. Now mind, you

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: little things, don't quarrel about the pieces: if you do, I won't give

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: you any more."

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,

PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: _No. 23.--Rabbit, Goat, and Hare._

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: Here are three very pretty animals. The first is a rabbit, of a kind,

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: gentle disposition. The second is a goat: he is by nature wild, and

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: jumps about from crag to crag, on his native mountains. The third is

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: the timid hare. I am afraid she is running from the pursuit of the dog.

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: Ah! what a cruel thing it is to set dogs to hunt this beautiful little

Poem Title: PRINTED FOR DARTON, HARVEY, AND DARTON,
line: animal.
